Posted By: Shikadi (8/16/2009 6:51:57 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I don't think it's that they actively sought to make it rare, but really, what else *could* it be? That sense of disbelief you get when you see it, the sputtering and slack-jawed, open-mouthed wonder that steals over you...it is not rare for its power, but rather for its power to infuriate you if you open it.  
  
One With Nothing, thank you for having the cojones to be different, challenging, and above all INFURIATING. 5/5
posts.html:

Posted By: ratchet1215 (8/31/2009 4:53:19 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
A very weak card, but not entirely without it's uses. It fuses nicely with surprise use of the Hellbent mechanic, and more than a few cards in the Shards of Alara Block. If you have [Sedris, the Traitor King](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sedris, the Traitor King) already in play and a handful of expensive creatures, for example, for 1 mana you suddenly have a graveyard full of very cheap creatures to chose from. You can also give [Lord of Extinction](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lord of Extinction) a quick boost, if he's looking a bit fragile or you just need one or two more P/T to make the difference between losing your creature and killing your opponent's.  
  
Okay, not brilliant ideas and about 4 years too late, but it's better than it used to be! =)
posts.html:
A very weak card, but not entirely without it's uses. It fuses nicely with surprise use of the Hellbent mechanic, and more than a few cards in the Shards of Alara Block. If you have Sedris, the Traitor King already in play and a handful of expensive creatures, for example, for 1 mana you suddenly have a graveyard full of very cheap creatures to chose from. You can also give Lord of Extinction a quick boost, if he's looking a bit fragile or you just need one or two more P/T to make the difference between losing your creature and killing your opponent's.

Okay, not brilliant ideas and about 4 years too late, but it's better than it used to be! =)

Posted By: DarkbladeWraith (7/8/2009 3:59:50 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
of course it might be useful in a *Hellbent* deck, but i prefer discarding cards slowly for an effect, e.g. through Spellshapers instead. Or via [Psychatog](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Psychatog) to have some fun with *Madness* effects.  
but dependant on format, there are [other](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=34470) [cheap](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=3255) [alternatives](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=132219), [also](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=3926) [with](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=29927) [different](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=29695) [colors](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=29777) to get rid of your hand.
posts.html:
of course it might be useful in a Hellbent deck, but i prefer discarding cards slowly for an effect, e.g. through Spellshapers instead. Or via Psychatog to have some fun with Madness effects.
but dependant on format, there are other cheap alternatives, also with different colors to get rid of your hand.

posts.post_content:
This is by far the worst card ever to see play in a modern Pro Tour. Ironically, it was used to combat the Owling Mine deck, a deck WotC didn't even know existed.  
  
Of course, the best players just played zoo, which rendered the matchup unwinnable for Owling Mine, but for those who didn't, this card came in handy in what was the dumbest answer to any deck ever.
posts.html:
This is by far the worst card ever to see play in a modern Pro Tour. Ironically, it was used to combat the Owling Mine deck, a deck WotC didn't even know existed.

Of course, the best players just played zoo, which rendered the matchup unwinnable for Owling Mine, but for those who didn't, this card came in handy in what was the dumbest answer to any deck ever.
